awd_titl_txt: Determinants of Hybrid Fitness and Genome Plasticity
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance understanding of hybrid organisms, which combine genomes from two different species. Hybrids can demonstrate new and desirable traits, performing better in some environments than either of the parent species. Because of this so-called 'hybrid vigor,' hybrids are very important in agriculture, and hybrid yeast specifically carry out many industrially important fermentation processes. Better understanding of hybrids will allow more effective breeding and engineering of improved crops and fermentation microorganisms. Despite this importance, hybrid genomes are not well understood, so this project has the potential to have high impact. In addition to its scientific impact, the project presents numerous training opportunities. A diverse team of undergraduate researchers will perform a significant portion of the experiments, and a postdoctoral fellow and graduate student will be trained in cutting edge genomics techniques. Outreach to the public will include education on yeast biology, fermentation and genome evolution, and the project will engage hobbyist and professional brewers in yeast genetics by enlisting their help to discover new hybrid yeasts.

This project will explore a number of open questions in hybrid genomics. It will discover how hybrids are able to adapt to new environments and develop new traits via three potential mechanisms: eliminating genetic conflicts, leveraging genetic variation, and taking advantage of transposon invasion.  Studying these hypotheses using naturally derived hybrids can be difficult because their history of growth environments is largely unknown. This project will apply a yeast experimental evolution approach to explore and understand these questions. Hybrids will be created in the lab and evolved under new environments. By sequencing the 'evolved' genomes, new mutations will be identified that have arisen in the population and achieved high frequency. Experiments will determine the relative contribution of genome rearrangements, point mutations, and transpositions to hybrid adaptation.  Comparison will then be undertaken with hybrids isolated from industrial and natural fermentations, some of which will be collected by brewers as part of this project. All together, the project will lead to better understanding of the molecular mechanisms important for hybrid vigor and adaptation.

This award is supported jointly by the Genetic Mechanisms program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and by the Environmental Sustainability program in the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems.

por.por_cntn:
Hybridization occurs when two different species mate. Hybrids can have unique characteristics that allow them to take advantage of having two different genomes, but they can also have sterility and growth problems due to incompatibilities between the species. Saccharomyces yeasts are a particularly good system in which to study hybridization because the various species can inter-mate, and the hybrids can be propagated mitotically, making them easy to study. In addition, the deep literature and large number of tools from the model system workhorse S. cerevisiae can be leveraged to understand the genetic and biochemical mechanisms underlying experimental observations.

Intellectual Merit: We studied the properties of S. cerevisiae/S. uvarum hybrids, including their capacity to adapt to new environments, the structure and stability of their genomes, and the contributions of individual genes to their growth abilities. Using experimental evolution in replicated and highly controlled conditions, we discovered that yeast hybrids do have enhanced flexibility to adapt to new environments, and that the genetic basis of that adaptation can be flipped between one parental genome or the other depending on the nature of the selective condition. In addition, we screened a collection of hybrids harboring deletions of individual genes, finding that the consequences of these mutations could be better or worse than in a purebred yeast strain. These results describe and explain some of the unique properties of hybrids.

In some hybrids, particularly with plant species, transposons (so-called “jumping genes”) appear to become misregulated. We did not observe this in yeast hybrids; however, we did discover a previously unknown role for mitochondria in modulating transposition rate. We don’t yet have a good explanation for this finding, which we hope to continue investigating in the future.

Broader Impacts: Finally, yeast hybrids are not just an important lab tool; they also are responsible for brewing lager beers and are frequently found in fermentation environments. Using a novel technique developed in our lab, we discovered a new interspecific hybrid yeast in an open-fermented beer sample. We have distributed the isolate to hundreds of professional and amateur brewers, many of whom have reported back to us with their observations of its use and behavior. Also, yeast don’t evolve only in the lab; they also evolve in the brewery. We applied our genomics tools to yeast samples collected over serial repitching, the brewing practice of reusing yeast for multiple brewing cycles. Amazingly, we saw the same kinds of genome changes that we did in the laboratory evolution experiments: changes in chromosome copy number, and changes in which parent of origin those copies are from. We have shared our results broadly in public talks, podcasts, webinars, and the popular press as a way for non-experts to learn about genome evolution.
